Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation Research Project: Effect of Self-Regulated Learning Development on Student Success in STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
North Carolina Central University (NCCU) proposes to examine the effect of self-regulated learning training and development on student success in STEM. The researchers propose to structure an intervention around units of a physics, chemistry, and calculus course and conduct a three-phase research project. Phase I will entail a pilot study to determine what learning strategies the STEM students currently use and a detailed analysis of the pilot data to identify gaps in effective self-regulated learning development. In Phase II, the researchers will develop and adapt a self-regulated learning training system for the students. Phase III will be an experimental study to investigate the effect of self-regulated learning training on student outcomes. Currently, little is known about the extent to which STEM students at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) use self-regulated learning strategies or develop the skills and competencies to do so. The proposed project will contribute knowledge to gain a better understanding of that phenomenon in the context of HBCUs with broader implications for minority students in STEM generally.

The fundamental aim of the research is to determine if improving self-regulated learning results in improved academic achievement in STEM at NCCU. A quasi-experimental design will be used to answer three research questions: (1) What learning strategies are NCCU STEM students currently using? The Motivated Strategies for Learning Questionnaire will be used to collect student motivation and self-regulated learning strategy data at the course/subject-specific level. (2) What gaps in effective self-regulated learning development exist for NCCU STEM students? The Pintrich model of self-regulated learning will be used to analyze the data collected in response to the first question to answer the second research question. Researchers will use the results of a synthesis of relevant literature to determine the best methodology and instructional strategies for conducting the self-regulated training - inside or outside the regular classroom. (3) Does self-regulated learning training enhance NCCU students' effective use of self-regulated strategies and change academic performance outcomes? Researchers will conduct a pre-post comparison of trait-oriented measures of self-regulated learning strategies using a questionnaire. The treatment group will complete surveys about their learning behavior during the study by receiving messages on their smartphones from SurveySignalÂ®. This research will produce data-driven information to create intervention models based on literature specific to the effects of self-regulation and motivation on student performance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this study is to determine if improving self-regulated learning of NCCU students supports their learning achievement in STEM. The main goal was to investigate the effects of training students in self-regulatory competence on achievement in STEM courses and as well as on the self-regulated learning development of students.  To reach this goal study of the self-regulated learning behaviors of NCCU students in STEM courses had to be conducted first. The study was structured around introductory physics, chemistry, and calculus courses. 

Intellectual Merit:

The Motivated Strategies for Learning Questionnaire (MSLQ) has been widely used to assess students’ usage of self-regulated learning (SRL) strategies in a course. Although numerous studies have been conducted utilizing the MSLQ, there have not been any to date with a study population consistent with that at NCCU.  Therefore, prior to conducting research on SRL in STEM education at NCCU, we conducted a study to establish the psychometric properties of the MSLQ for our study population (STEM students who attend NCCU) to establish the reliability and validity which would result from use of the MSLQ instrument. we administered the full MSLQ to students in 18 classes from the subject areas of Physics, Chemistry and Mathematics at NCCU.  The response rate was approximately 65% of 488, for a total of 316 completing the survey. Fifty-eight cases had various missing item data and were removed. The final sample size was 258 with no missing MSLQ item data. Academic performance was measured by collecting end-of-course (EOC) grades for the classes used in this study. 

Confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) was conducted on the factor structure of the MSLQ to investigate the psychometric properties. Both the motivation section and learning strategies section models of

the MSLQ fail to fit the HBCU sample data. Having unsatisfactory model fit results, CFA procedures

were used to respecify the factorial structure to better account for the observed data. The resulting respecified measure, MSLQ-R, consisted of 48 of the original 81 items that were structured in 11 scales, four 1st-order factors, and two 2nd-order factors.

 

The current study looked at the predictability of motivation on the self-regulated learning propensities presented by students in the HBCU Sample from the MSLQ-R.  The intrinsic value expressed was the strongest predictor on all of the cognitive strategy use variables. Students expressing high intrinsic value for the STEM course they were taking, strongly endorsed their engagement in critical thinking, organization, elaboration, metacognitive self-regulation, and rehearsal learning strategies. However, as evidenced by the significant negative relationships with their expressed control of learning beliefs, students did not expect to be successful in using the specific cognitive strategies they endorsed. Similarly, the task value that students expressed had the strongest effect on the time & study environment management and effort regulation they expressed. Again, their expectancy for success, via control of learning beliefs, was related negatively. 

Results from the current study finds that for the HBCU Sample, students’ expressed self-efficacy is the strongest predictor of course performance and academic achievement, and it is the singular predictor when controlling for prior achievement.  Neither metacognitive self-regulation nor any of the other cognitive learning strategies was predictive of course performance for the HBCU Sample. 

Broader Impacts:

The current study examined differences in self-regulated learning propensities by achievement level of students. Large effect differences by achievement levels measured by MSLQ-R for motivation (self-efficacy) and self-regulation (time & study environment management and effort regulation) variables, shows MSLQ-R distinguishes between high from low achieving groups. This capacity of the MSLQ-R to differentiate by achievement level has utility for both research and practice.
